Tim had a red hat and a big cat.

Bob and his men got the bid for a fish
job.

The men had to lug the

Bob did check the net
and it did not lack fish.

The net had six big
fish in it.
This job was a hit!

Then, the ship had to get back to the
dock.

When the ship was at the dock, the

stories.title: Josh and His Pet Chick
stories.text: Josh had to check on his pet chick in the pen. The pen was set in back of a shack. The pet chick was a hen and had a tad bit of red on the top. Josh did dash to the shack and run in the pen. Then Josh did pick up his pet chick to hug. The chick was fed and it did hop and peck. Then Josh did lock the pen back up to let the chick nap. It was a fun job to have a pet chick.

A Bad Call

It was fall with a bit of a chill.

Rich got

Now Zip was full of

stories.title: A Bath for the Pup
stories.text: Jill had a big pup. She did call him Ziff. The pup did run and run. Ziff did run up a hill and then to a log. To top it off, Ziff did run in the mud. At the end of his run, Ziff was a mess! Jill led Ziff to the tub in a rush. Ziff had to get a bath. But, Ziff did not want to get wet at all. Ziff sat and did not hop in the tub as Jill did wish. What did Jill do? Jill did not quit! She had to get Ziff to dip into the tub. Then, Jill got a ball and she gave it a toss into the tub. Ziff was quick to hop to the ball. Ziff was in the tub and all wet after all.

stories.title: The Man with the Red Hat
stories.text: A man with a red hat sits on a dock. He does want to fish, but he does not have a rod. He is sad, but he sits on the dock until the sun sets. When he gets up to go to the bus, he sees six ducks. The ducks quack and quack. They make the man with the red hat not so sad. One of the ducks sits by the man's leg. The duck rubs his bill up and down on the man's leg as if to tell him, "Do not be sad!" The man tips his red hat to his new duck pal, then jogs off and hops on the bus.

stories.title: The Fish Tank
stories.text: Liz set the fish in the tank one by one. Then, Liz asked her dad if they could get rocks for the tank. Liz's dad did tell her yes, but she had to go to bed now. Liz fed the fish, sang them a quick song, and then got in her bed. The next day, Liz and her dad had to go to the bank to get cash. Then, they would set off for Chang's pet shop. At the shop, they got a bag of fish tank rocks and other things for Liz's pets. When Liz set the pink rocks in the tank, they sank. What did the fish think about that? They were quick to get used to the pink rocks and other things. The fish in Liz's tank were set up to have a long and fun life!

stories.title: The Lost Brush
stories.text: Mom sent Ted to get her black brush, but it was not in its spot. It was the best brush to Mom and now it was lost. Mom was just so sad as she asked, "Where could it be?" Ted and Mom then went on a hunt for the brush. They had a plan to check all the spots it could be. Ted got a stiff brush from the chest at the end of the bed. He got a soft brush from a box next to the tub. Yet, both Mom and Ted could not dig up that one black brush. With a tilt of his neck, Ted asked, "What should we do?" Mom had to tell Ted, "Let us just rest for now. I think you have been a big help. We did try, yet my best brush is still lost!" The next week, Mom had to dust the den. She held onto the top of a lamp to dust it. She felt her hand grip what must be the black brush. It was there! Who would think to check in a lamp? With her black brush back, Mom had a big grin on her lips. Ted was glad as well. No more brush hunts for now!

stories.title: Old Junk or Not?
stories.text: Fran has been coming to the junk lot since she was a small child. She has to hunt many stacks of trash to find things that she wants. It can take a long time to get the best pick of the lot, but Fran does not mind. What does she plan to do with all this old junk? Fran has a gift. She can get any old thing to look new again. Fran was in luck and did find an old gold lamp on this trip to the junk lot. It had rust on the top and a big crack on the rim, but Fran did think, "This is it! My next task." A kind man at the desk sold Fran the lamp for just one buck. Then, Fran put the lamp in her van and set off to put her many skills to the job. She had to fix the crack in the rim and dust off the rust. In the wink of an eye, that old lamp had become anything but junk. In fact, when Fran had to host a lunch the next week, most of her pals were wild about her gold lamp. They told her that they could not think of a shop anywhere that would have a lamp like that. Fran did not tell anyone that the lamp was from the junk lot. With a grin, she just told them, "Thank you. You are too kind!"

stories.title: When the Kids are Out
stories.text: Mom and Dad were the only ones in the den. Their kids were out and about. Mom had to print out some bills and Dad had to fold some pants and tops. Dad asked Mom where the kids were. She told him that Bill went to the swim club to do some laps. Bill had said he would then get lunch with a friend. Mom said, "I trust that he will back by six p.m. Why do you ask about where the kids are?" Dad then asked, "What about Jen?" Mom said that Jen went to the dress shop. Her old dress had a big rip in the front of it. Then Jen had plans to stop by Gram's. Jen said that she wanted to spend time doing crafts with Gram. "That is grand," said Dad. "We can have brunch, and then I will get the deck of cards from the trunk." Mom had to blink and think. Then, she said, "Now I know why you asked where the kids were. You had plans all along to crush me at a game of cards!"

stories.title: Thanks, from the Fish
stories.text: The fish in Liz's tank swam past the tall plants. The fish were now big - and strong too. Liz had been the best pet mom! Every two weeks, Liz had to work to clean everything in the fish tank. She had a list to prompt her to do each step. Step 1: Liz had to scrub the glass with a stiff brush. Step 2: Liz had to rub every pink rock. Step 3: Liz had to also scrub the front, sides, and back of the tank. In the midst of each tank scrub, it struck Liz that there was not too much stress with this task. In fact, it felt very good to get rid of the mess on everything. At the end of the job, the tank was set until the next scrub! If the fish could chat, they would tell Liz, "Thanks!"

stories.title: Montel's Job at the Kennel
stories.text: Montel was all set for his first day on the job at the kennel. He would work there seven days each month. He would get some cash, but he could still pull off the work for his classes. Montel met his boss, Mrs. Hoffman. She was kind and went on to discuss everything about his job. She gave Montel a map of the kennel and told him that they would often have a big number of cats and dogs. Some of the pets would come for one or two days, but some would come for a long spell. The kennel would be full on most days. Montel got to see the block of kennels for cats only. There were big old cats and small kittens. Then, Mrs. Hoffman led Montel into a tunnel to see where they kept the dogs. They had lapdogs and also many grand dogs. Montel could tell that the staff had to commit to have the best kennel. For the first month, Montel would work with Mrs. Hoffman to find out how to lock and unlock the pens, scrub the kennel walls, and unpack the tidbits for the pet dishes. Then, he would get to help with the pet baths. Montel was very glad about his first shift on the job and ran off to tell everyone about his work.

stories.title: Alfred and the Dentist
stories.text: Alfred had a problem. He had to go see the new dentist down at the children's clinic next month. Her name was Dr. Clifton. This made Alfred so very sad. He did not want to make the dentist mad, but Alfred had a distrust for these kinds of things. He could not help but ask himself, "What if this dentist has to pull out my front teeth?" At last, Alfred told his dad. He did express that he did not want to go see the dentist. His dad said, "First, do not get upset over this. You should not panic about a trip to the dentist, Alfred. You must go and it will not be as bad as you think." Alfred said, "I still wish I did not have to go. I tell you, I will not have any fun at that clinic." Then Dad said, "Dr. Clifton will just check and floss your teeth. She will not pull anything out. You have my word on that! I still insist that you go, and then you will tell me that it was not a big problem after all. Trust me." Alfred put his hands under his chin and said, "OK, I will try this new dentist for you."

stories.title: An Insect Picnic
stories.text: Mr. and Mrs. Robbins collect their bags and set off under the sun. It is not a long walk to the district park, but they will get to talk and connect as they walk. Mr. and Mrs. Robbins know the public spot will be full. This is the kind of day that attracts many people who have the day off from work. They are right to suspect that the park is busy. Mr. and Mrs. Robbins pick a spot to put their blanket and bags of snacks and drinks. Did they expect what happens next? Not so much! You see, there is a visit to the blanket by a string of insects - ants, to be exact! Mr. and Mrs. Robbins brush off the insects so they do not get in contact with the drinks and snacks. In the end, Mr. and Mrs. Robbins do not let this attack impact the splendid day, even if the insects think the picnic is for them!

stories.title: Basketball Camp
stories.text: Jess runs around with a big grin. She is always wild about basketball camp. Jess thinks basketball camp is the most fantastic thing in the world. She attends every six months and is sad and discontent when she is not there. Jess has big plans to accomplish many things at basketball camp this time. She wants to be the best at the drills and exhibit her talent and skill. Her legs tend to cramp up when she runs a lot, so that can be a problem. But, Jess knows it will all work out. She may even establish herself as the number one kid on the team! The basketball camp is in Galveston, an hour away. Jess and her pal, Alex, want to hop on a bus to get there. Jess's dad says they could do the trip in their new van, but Jess does not like that idea. Jess says, "Dad, I do not want to go in our van. I want to go to Galveston on the bus with Alex, just the two of us. We are old enough now and you can trust us." Jess's dad will let them travel by bus and he will not go with them. But, he tells Jess not to exhibit any misconduct on the trip. Jess tells her dad not to stress. She just wants to be a basketball champ.

stories.title: The Shrinking Cat
stories.text: Will Benton was just two when he got his pet cat, Jazz. She was only a small ball of fluff back then, but now she is a great big cat! Jazz is always rushing throughout the house. She dashes after balls when Will tosses them to her. Then, you can often spot Jazz resting on Will's bed for a nap. This cat and her friend, Will, have been bonding for a long time now. One day, Will hands Jazz her red ball, but Jazz twists and walks off. Will thinks that this is odd. Next, Jazz sits next to her dish, but when Will drops her food down to her, Jazz does not want to snack. She limps off past her water dish. Will knows something is not right. When he bends down to pick up his pet, he can tell Jazz has shrunk! Will yells to his mom. Mrs. Benton rushes in and says, "Oh my Will, what is all this talk about shrinking cats?" Will says, "It's our Jazz! She is not snacking. She is not drinking. I think she is sick." Mrs. Benton sits down to check on the cat and says, "Will, you are right. We should be rushing her away to the vet right now!" So, off they all go. After a quick check by the vet, Jazz gets a shot. The vet tells Will and his Mom, "This cat should be resting for an hour after this shot. Try putting her down for a nap when you get back home. Then when she gets up, she should be drinking and snacking just fine. No more shrinking cats!"

stories.title: A Cake for Mrs. Blake
stories.text: The clock strikes six and Devin jumps out of bed. It's time to get going. He is off to work at the bake shop. Devin's big task for the day is to bake a fantastic cake for Mrs. Blake. She plans to come into the shop at two o'clock to pick up the custom-made cake. Devin's first step is to mix the contents to make a cake batter. Then, it's time to bake the cake in a pan. When the cake is done, it will have to sit out until it is not hot. Mrs. Blake does not want a cake with lumps or one that tips to one side. So, Devin has to start with a great cake base. He uses the level-and-split method and makes sure to remove the top of the cake so that it is flat. Next, Devin uses the frosting like a paste and wipes it onto a cake board. This way the cake sticks to the board when Devin sets it down. Using a knife, Devin then cuts around the sides of the cake with care. He keeps going until the cake is split in two. Then, he removes the top half. Using a stiff frosting, Devin pipes a dam in the shape of a circle onto the cake. Then, he fills the middle with a rich lime jam. To finish things off, Devin puts the top of the cake back and frosts it. Mrs. Blake is sure to be glad when she takes a taste of this cake!

stories.title: The Costume Ball
stories.text: Kate put on her homemade costume for the fifth-grade fall ball. She was dressing as a dragon and her classmate, Mike, was going as a cat. Kate was quick to get ready. Her mom had to help so her dragon makeup would look good. She told Mike to get a move on because she did not want to miss the ball. It would be bedtime soon, and that was no fun to think about. When Kate and Mike both had their costumes on, they knew they should get going. Kate's mom gave them a ride to the ball. On the way, Kate and Mike could not stop talking about how Eve, the host, almost had to postpone the ball. There was no way to foretell that the band would quit on the very day of the ball! However, Eve went on to hire a DJ, and she hosted the ball just the same. When Kate and Mike got to the ball, there was a spine-chilling pumpkin at the front gatepost. The two pals went inside, and Eve handed them homemade milkshakes and kingsize cupcakes. Kate and Mike had a blast! This was the best fall ball yet!

stories.title: A Japanese Lunch
stories.text: Ren is from Japan, but as of last year, her home is in Dallas, Texas. Ren likes to share things from her Japanese life with her friends. Ren invites her pal, Filip, to come over and have lunch one day. Ren tells Filip that she will make him a Japanese dish for lunch. Filip is pleased that Ren would think to do this for him. Ren must recognize that he has not had a Japanese lunch before. Once Filip is at Ren's home, he is quick to contribute. The two work together to finish the job of making lunch. Filip takes a look in the pan and sees a dish like nothing he's ever seen before. It looks like a pancake, but it has shrimp, fish, and crisp vegetables. Ren's home smells fantastic! Filip wants to dig in right away! Ren demonstrates to Filip how to grill the pancake so that it is not left incomplete. The pancakes get put on plates. Then, the two friends sit and snack on Japanese pancakes and sip on some lemonade.

stories.title: No Olives for Me!
stories.text: Do not be sad, but I say there is nothing in the world that tastes as bad as an olive. I sound like a critic, but I do not like them on my salads. I never did. I do not like them with my fish, and please do not put them in my chicken salad! I know you are going to say, "Just taste one. They are very good." However, I used to try to like these black and green things. Once, I had to rinse the taste away with a gallon of water after just one bite! One day, my friend Melvin found a new store and bought a jug of fresh olives. He went home and made fresh club sandwiches, then he called to invite me to have lunch with him. Melvin thought it would be a good joke to place the olives inside the sandwiches without telling me. I should recognize that Melvin would do something like this because he is always up to some kind of nonsense. I bit the sandwich and could tell right away. Olives! Yuck! I know that I should think about more constructive and important things. I should not be so tense about my dislike for this small food with pits, but I am against them, I tell you that!

stories.title: A New School
stories.text: Today is a big day for Beth Fry! It is her first day at a new school, and she will be in the fourth grade. Beth moved to her new home just four days ago. Her old home is very far away. In fact, it is in a different state. Beth is sad as she stands at the bus stop. Her mom stands by her and says, "Do not cry, Beth. Things will be different, but it will be fine in the end." Beth nods and smiles, but she is shy and has a tough time when it comes to trying new things. Before long, the bus comes. Beth tells herself to be strong as she gets on and looks for a spot to sit. She finds one at the front of the bus next to two other kids. They look at her name tag and say, "Hi Beth!" The three kids talk while the bus makes several more stops. When the bus stops in front of the school, one of Beth's new friends says, "We ought to grab our lunch bags and backpacks now. The bell will ring in five minutes and we do not want to be late for class." Beth thinks that her mom may have been right. Things will be just fine.

stories.title: Mom's Big Day
stories.text: It was Mom's birthday so Rachel and Jaden wanted to make the day great for her. They woke up early and went right out to shop. When they got to the store, Rachel and Jaden put several pink tulips and white lilacs in their basket. Then they bought chunks of fresh melon, bagels, jumbo cupcakes, and a jug of cold lemonade. The plan was to get everything set up before Mom woke up. The man at the store learned about their important plans and rang up their items as fast as he could. After Rachel and Jaden handed over the cash, they ran to the local gift shop. There, they got Mom some new sunglasses. Then, the siblings sprinted back toward the house. Rachel and Jaden put the tulips and lilacs in a vase with water. Next, they put glasses out for the lemonade. They moved the bagels and cupcakes onto the most attractive plate they owned. The final step was to put picks in the melon chunks so there would be zero problems picking them up. Now, they just had to hold off until Mom got up. When Mom woke up, her smile said it all. Everything was a hit! She was pleased and thought in her heart that she had the best kids in the world!

stories.title: Amy and the Pony
stories.text: Amy is a very active young lady. Not only does she study a lot, but she also spends time helping at a local animal rescue. Today, Amy thought she would spend the entire day working with the animals. Most of the time, it is her duty to take care of a lazy kitty, Andy, and a silly dog, Teddy. They both require care because they were very sick for a long time. However, today was going to be different from most days. A pony at the rescue would have a baby, and Amy would get to help! Every person at the rescue would move fast all day. There was a lot to do to make sure everything went well. Amy had to empty the entry to the barn and make sure there was a cozy place for the pony, Ruby, to rest. There was plenty for everyone to do! When Amy was done with all her tasks, a woman came in. She was a vet who was there to help Ruby. In the end, everything went very well! Amy was so happy she was dizzy! The pony was beautiful. Amy was sure this was the best day the rescue ever had!

stories.title: A Code to Be Safe
stories.text: Being in seventh grade is going to be a blast! I will be attending a new school, and I have been granted the duty to babysit my sister each day after school gets out. My mother and father will not be home from work until six p.m. They are going to put a lot of trust in me, but I am up for the job. My mother and father are proactive people. They bought a new program to make the house safe for my sister and me. It will keep us protected and keep all others from coming into the house. There is a small box with a restricted code for entry. It cost my parents a lot of cash to get it in place. Each component is connected with wires so the signals will transmit to the control panel. The handyman was quick to finish the work. My sister and I will now be in a safe environment, and my mother and father will not be insecure. They said, "Nothing is more important than our son and daughter!" There is only one problem with this plan. I have to recall the code to unlock the house, and my father says I cannot write the number down. Someone could find it and then use it to get into the house. More than three mistakes when punching in the code will set off the bells and sirens. I must study the code and develop a way to fix it in my mind. So, that's what I am going to do! I will get it!

stories.title: Ribbons
stories.text: Amanda is so happy. The day that she has been longing for is here at last! Amanda is five years old, and soon she will be the last child in her family to begin school at the academy. Amanda is happy to join her brothers and sisters in school and demonstrate the same positive attitude. Almost all the families on Amanda's block have kids that go to the same school. Amanda is so pleased when she thinks about traveling on the bus like them. The woman who drives the bus has a funny habit of granting a cute nickname to each student. Amanda is aware of this and can't wait for hers. When Amanda is almost set to go, her mom fixes three small identical satin ribbons onto her hair. Amanda and her siblings exit the house and run toward the bus stop. The bus will be coming soon, and they all want to try to get there extra early. When Amanda runs up the steps of the bus, she says a quick hello to the bus lady. The woman takes one look at Amanda and says, "Hi, Ribbons!" Amanda gives the lady a wide smile and, at that moment, she knows that everything is going to be great!

stories.title: The Planting Club
stories.text: Becky had a love for anything that had to do with the outside world. When she began seventh grade, she quickly drafted a plan for the establishment of an after-school planting club. She was hopeful that the school would say yes and that a few other students would enlist in the club. Becky had been right to be hopeful. To her amazement, the school's answer was yes! They gladly adopted the hands-on program, and ten other students quickly became part of the club. The school had even presented a small plot of land behind the school to the thankful club! The objective of the club was to develop crops that were good for the public and the planet. The students had to commit to meet a minimum of once a week. Above all, they had to be proactive with their planting tasks. Soon, they were working for the common good, planting and picking their crops. It could be messy work, but the club stuck to their objectives. They used things like food waste to put in the soil to grow their goods. The club sold their crops in front of the school each day. Adults would drop off their kids, then gladly stop at the stand to pick up fresh products from the planting club. They would drive off with a bagful of things like tomatoes, beans, and spinach.

stories.title: Mr. Post's Big Hit
stories.text: One day, Mr. Post told his fifth-grade students that he had something thrilling to share. He was beginning an after-school book club! It would meet once a week and anyone could come. Each month the students in the club would read a book picked by Mr. Post. Each month would focus on a different theme. The first month, the book would be about the oceans of Earth. The second month, the book was to be a tale set on a remote American island in the Atlantic. Kevin looked around the class, and all he could see were the smiles. They all felt that this club was going to be a big hit. They were right! Ten students came to the first book club meeting. Mr. Post unpacked the big box on his desk and handed out a book to each student. He told them that they were going to love this topic, and he expected them to read through the first two parts of the book by the time they met next. Mr. Post said that the students would be asked to discuss the book and debate the facts. Kevin thanked Mr. Post, stuffed the book into his backpack, and dashed home as fast as he could. He wanted to tell his mom and dad about this new club he belonged to. Kevin finished the first two parts of the book and took notes in his notebook. He wanted to be sure he could recall the facts when the club met again. Kevin felt that this book club was the best thing that happened in fifth grade!

stories.title: The Golf Lesson
stories.text: Mindy had wanted to learn how to play golf for a long time. When she came across an online ad for golf lessons, she called the number and set up a time for the first of eight lessons. She only had two days to get all the equipment in place for her first lesson. So, Mindy carefully made a list in her notepad and drove to the golf shop. There were no other customers at the shop. Mindy was impressed with all the helpers the shop had on staff. They actively assisted her as she collected all the items she had on her list; clubs, balls, shoes, and clothes. She picked out an attractive red golf bag, and she even bought a large hat to protect herself from the hot sun. Mindy went back home to unpack all her new things. Thankfully, she was set for her golf lesson! On the day of her golf lesson, Mindy got to the golf club with all her belongings just before sunrise. She was shocked to see a long line of golf students, but only two instructors. She said to herself, "How am I going to learn this game of golf with all these other people?" The students were told to follow the instructors. They moved from one hole to another where they learned how to effectively hit the golf balls. Mindy's stroke was not the best at first. One of the instructors told her that she was stiffening her neck and hands too much. With a few adjustments, her swing got more exact. By the eighth hole, she could tell she was skillfully getting the hang of it. She had to laugh as the other students were losing their golf balls left and right. With seven more lessons to come, Mindy would surely be a pro at the game of golf!

stories.title: Bubble Gum Habit
stories.text: Monty always had a pack of bubble gum in his pocket. He was constantly chomping on the sticky stuff! Monty's mother told him that all that bubble gum would be trouble for his teeth. Still, it was impossible for him to stop. Monty munched and chomped on large sticks and chunks of gum all day. He would use a double chunk of gum to make jumbo-size bubbles. Although he got in trouble for it, Monty snacked on his gum during school too. One day, Monty was told he had to stop, or he would be sent out of class. Monty was a good student, so he had to think quickly! Monty felt he was ready to stop his bad gum habit. He knew he was capable, so he made a plan to cut back to just one or two sticks of bubble gum each day. He also kept a bottle of water with him at all times. When he had a desire for gum, he would take a little sip of some water in place of a stick of pink or red gum. Even though it was difficult to give up his bubble gum, Monty knew it was best to just have some every now and then.
